message.content:
cs.LG, cs.SY, cs.NE, cs.AI, cs.DS 

The paper deals with the application of the Pontryagin's maximum principle (PMP) to the training of deep learning algorithms, which involves the formulation of necessary optimality conditions in continuous time. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the sub-category of cs.LG (Machine Learning), which deals with the development and application of algorithms that enable computers to learn from data. The paper also involves the use of control theory to recast the training problem as a control problem, which suggests that it may belong to the sub-category of cs.SY (Systems and Control), which deals with the analysis and design of systems that exhibit dynamical behavior. Additionally, the paper discusses the convergence properties of the proposed algorithm, which suggests that it may belong to the sub-category of cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing), which deals with the study of neural networks and other biologically-inspired algorithms. The paper also discusses the limitations of gradient-based methods, which suggests that it may belong to the sub-category of cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence), which deals with the development of intelligent agents that can perform tasks that typically require human-level intelligence. Finally, the paper involves the use of mathematical techniques to solve optimization problems, which suggests that it may belong to the sub-category of cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms), which deals with the design and analysis of algorithms for solving computational problems.
